Posts.Title: Unreal, high feeling--is this chemo brain? ordinarymammal ordinarymammal

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 01:19PM mbtlcsw01 wrote: I am grateful they do MRI's for women today.  My cancer, the size of a walnut, was not seen on a mammogram.  I had very, very dense breast tissue and was never offered to have an MRI--which would have been protocol, since my mom and grandmother had bc.  Be grateful this is all available to you--many women have gone before us who did not have the technology that is available to us today.  Prayers are with you.

Posts.Content: May 19, 2010 05:35PM mbtlcsw01 wrote: Hello Annson.  What a jewel you are for your mom.  I am a bit younger and have 3 adult sons 32, 29 and 27.  You know a great deal more about your mom's cancer than any of mine did. You pretty much hit it right on the head.  We moms will do anything to protect our children, no matter how old they are.  On her journey, she will good and bad days.  Very likely, she doesn't want your life to be "all about her."  Be there as a support to her when she needs it, but continue on with your own life and tell her about it.  It helps for us to have something else to talk and think about besides ourselves during this time.  Be sure to take care of yourself during this journey.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 08:50AM mbtlcsw01 wrote: Joanne, I thank God for that person to have the courage to nudge you in that direction.  My tumor was missed repeatedly on mamo because I have dense breast tissue.  The last mamo indicated everything was ok, and they called off the ultrasound.  I found it several months later and it was about 2 cm IDC stage 1 grade 3.  I support your decision for the BMX, it was a no brainer for me.  My nipple had begun to look different and that is what made me go back to have it checked.  We are all here for you.  Blessings.
Posts.Title: My story--a mam.tech saved my life Joanne58 Joanne58

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2010 04:33AM - edited Jun 4, 2010 04:34AM by mbtlcsw01 Elizabeth is absolutely and totally right.  I'm a licensed clinical social worker.  I STRONGLY urge you to talk to someone and get on some antidepressants before you make this decision.  Your mood is already low and it is very hard to make an informed decision in that state.  Once your mood can come up a few notches, you will be better able to handle these "life things."  They are not easy and it is not always fun, but it would be very helpful for you to find something in your life you are curious about.  Think back on better years.  What did you like to do--simple things like talking to a friend, riding a bike, growing a plant.  We can find so much more meaning in life today going back to those things of our youth which intrigued us.  As Elizabeth said, heal the mind to help heal the body.  HUGS and best thoughts to you, Mary

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 12:48AM mbtlcsw01 wrote: I completely agree it is an idividual choice.  My family history made the decision for me.  I always believed it was not if but when I would be dx.  My grandmother had it and it killed my mom.  My mom had one mx and 9 months later had to have the other mx.  I decided then if I were dx, I would have a bi lat mast.  I did not want to have to get on that roller coaster again.  I saw my mom's journey and decided I was not so bonded to my breasts that I would let it kill me.  Did BRAC testing later and found I was BRAC 2 positive.  I've had reconstruction and don't feel "mutliated" as that doc referred to it.  I would sugget that doc just have 3 lumpectomies herself (propholacitly of course) and then go to Victoria's Secret for that special bra.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 02:39AM mbtlcsw01 wrote: Hi 2new1s.  Your questions are not dumb.  I'm having TE exchange on 11.30.09 and an oopherectomy at the same time.  I told both surgeons to do whatever they could to take as much off/out of me that would be covered under my insurance.  We said it jokingly, but I know my PS does lipo to fill in around the new implants to make a "nice drape."  Not sure how much can be done as a tummy tuck--I;ll be interested to find out what happens with you cause I have to have the nipple part done next year.  Blessings.
Posts.Title: Tummy tuck/nipple reconstruction/Exchange ?'s 2new1s 2new1s

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2010 09:12AM mbtlcsw01 wrote: I had dense breast tissue, but did not know it.  I also had a very strong family history of bc.  One thing you need to know is to insist on a breast MRI to get a baseline.  As leaf said, mammos miss things when you have dense breast tissue.  It completely missed my tumors the size of a walnut--I had them bring the mammos out to me to see and sure enough, it was not visible on a mammo.  The medical protocol is to have an MRI if you have dense breast tissue and a strong family history. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/409021_7

Posts.Content: May 19, 2010 08:43PM mbtlcsw01 wrote: Yearbookteach, I don't know where you live and if you have insurance that will cover it, but if you know your breast tissue is dense and to set your mind at ease, you should insist on a breast MRI.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 03:00AM mbtlcsw01 wrote: 2new1s  I also lost about 50 pounds before I was dx with BC.  I was dx with type 2 diabetes prior to all this so I got serious about losing the weight.  gained about 20 of it back during chemo.  I have LOTS of skin and had hoped to do some type of flap, but just cannot take that much time off of work to mend.  I'm very happy with my new girls--was filled up to 920 cc.  Great size D's and my hair came back in absolutley great.  Let me know what you can get your docs to do.  I'm going to really push for as much lipo and mini tuck as I can.

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 03:32PM mbtlcsw01 wrote: Jean, I'm having an oopherectomy along with my exchange of TE's end of November.  I had already gone thru menopause naturally 7 years ago.  Have SE's from femara that I have to take for a long time and like you, have a hot flash or two in the evenings.  I made the decision about the tubes coming out because I had BRAC testing and I'm positive for a BRAC 2 mutation.  This does increase my likelihood of cancer showing up again, that is why I'm doing it.  Did you have genetic testing done?
Posts.Title: Remove ovaries after treatment, Yes or No? Jean09 Jean09

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2010 08:44PM mbtlcsw01 wrote: edancer, I too was dx in Oct 2008.  The day I got the news, I called the nurse practitioner back and asked her if she really had told me I had bc.  It was so surreal.  Don't know your age, etc. I did have a strong family hx, but had mammo's since I was 34 and was dx when I was 54.  Mammo would have never picked it up--dense breast tissue.  I found it myself. Take a deep breath.  I was already prepared that when the day came, I would have a bilateral mast. and I did.  My husband of over 30 years was brave and supportive, but he later said he had to catch up with me.  There are many, many reconstruction options if you choose to have a double mast or even a single.  I've had reconstruction and really am happy with my created breasts--with nipples, too. Just take all this one step at a time.  Yes, friends and family say some stupid things like "you are so brave,  be positive."  They have not learned yet how unhelpful this is.  No we are scared to death and so are they. You have found a group of sisters here who will be with you the whole way.  Read all the educational stuff and look through the threads for discussions of things you are going through.  Ask questions.  We are here for you.  Blessings to you.  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: guess I am having a mastectomy! edancer hymil

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2010 10:28AM mbtlcsw01 wrote: Happy Birthday Dream.  Be blessed on your day.
Posts.Title: HAPPY Birthday, Dream!! faithandfifty chainsawz

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 07:03PM mbtlcsw01 wrote: cka0706  great topic.  I'm also now a one year survivor and about to have my exchange from te's at the end of the month.  I was excited to reach the 1 year mark, but it has been a let down since with some depression.  Someone else said it well.  There was alot of attention given to me during treatment, etc. by friends, co-workers, etc., but now all that is pretty much over.  I don't particularly like attention to myself, but got used to it.  As said above, now we're pretty much alone.  My wonderful DH and I had our first disagreement last week in a year.  We both laughed and cried together because it was the first time he was able to be angry with me.  I saw this as progress because now he's able to treat me as he did before.   Today I had to go to Moffitt Cancer Center to get ready for the oophrectomy being done same day as the exchange.  I almost lost it during an imaging procedure because it reminded me so much of the biopsy a year before.  I was so exhausted from just being there, I had to take the rest of the day off.  Alot of this is grief and loss and learning how to deal with it.  I went into auto pilot when I was diagnosed.  A year later I'm finally feeling the feelings.  It is hard for some people to understand.  Hang in there, sisters, we will make it.
Posts.Title: Been handling this ... until today cka0706 kel1

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 05:41PM mbtlcsw01 wrote: My mom and grandmother had  BC. My mom lost her life to it.  It was because of them and so many of our other sisters before us who have died with this terrible disease, that we have been blessed with this technology to understand our cancer down to the moelcular level and make decisions about treatment.  Those before us did not have that luxury.  My score was just past the high risk mark.  It was a no brainer to have chemo.  My niece recently has gone through all this.  Her oncotype score was low.  She does not need it.  She can thank her grandmother and great grandmother for what they went through to now have this edge to know what treatment is best. it is each persons responsiblity to educate herself and research as said before.  And thank those who went before us.  If you don't need chemo, thank a previous sister who helped along the way to learn this.
